thread.title: 20 things to see, hear and do this weekend
thread.title_full: 20 things to see, hear and do this weekend

author: canberratimes.com.au
title: 20 things to see, hear and do this weekend
text:
Shy and retiring characters KISS perform at Allphones Arena on Saturday. 
1. STAGE: THE REAL THING
Tom Stoppard's teasingly brilliant play about love and fidelity is the story of Charlotte, an actress in a play about marriage written by her husband, Henry. Max, her leading man, is also married to an actress, Annie. Then Henry and Annie fall in love. But is it the real thing? Alice Livingstone directs. Ainslie McGlynn and Chris Tomkinson​ feature. EB
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 7.30PM, NEW THEATRE, NEWTOWN, $17-$32, NEWTHEATRE.ORG.AU 
2. STAGE: GHOSTS
Advertisement It's opening night for Depot Theatre's production of Henrik Ibsen's Ghosts , the story of an unhappy widow and her prodigal son, an artist who has inherited syphilis through the debauchery of his supposedly upstanding father. One critic described Ghosts as "a loathsome sore unbandaged" when the play debuted in London in 1891. Reason enough to see it, we think. EB
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 8PM, DEPOT THEATRE, MARRICKVILLE, $24-$29, THEDEPOTTHEATRE.COM 
3. STAGE: A RABBIT FOR KIM JONG-IL
Kit Brookman's new play previews from tonight. Based on a true story, it's the story of one farmer, his giant bunny rabbits, and what happens when they come to the attention of the Supreme Leader of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Lee Lewis directs, Steve Rodgers stars, and Brookman​ plays a jumbo bunny called Felix. EB
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 7PM, GRIFFIN THEATRE, KINGS CROSS, $35-$55, GRIFFINTHEATRE.COM.AU 
4. ART: WOOLLAHRA SMALL SCULPTURE PRIZE 2015
The exhibition features the work of 43 artist finalists selected from more than 700 entries. This year's highlights include Tully Arnott's slightly skittish Nervous Plant , the brightly coloured Mal from John Nicholson (pictured) and James and Eleanor Avery's high-gloss Instabear . A program of events that includes a chat with the artists and a family workshop runs over the weekend. Check the website for details and bookings. SW
UNTIL OCTOBER 25 WOOLLAHRA COUNCIL CHAMBERS, WOOLLAHRA, SCULPTUREPRIZE.WOOLLAHRA.NSW.GOV.AU 
5. ART: GREY MATTER
If Fifty Shades of Grey proved that grey was not the lifeless colour it once seemed, Artbank's new exhibition, Grey Matter, aims to do the same. Drawn from the Artbank collection by curator Mark Feary, the display focuses on works with a restrained palette and a broad sense of black and white pairings, opposites and extremes. Opening with the decisive simplicity of Paddy Guwumji Bedford's Camel Back , the show traverses mediums from painting and sculpture to the wonderful hijacking of Bob Dylan's iconic Subterranean Homesick Blues music clip by Soda_Jerk in their video The Popular Front . SW
UNTIL NOVEMBER 28, ARTBANK GALLERY, WATERLOO, ARTBANK.GOV.AU 
6. FAMILY: VAUCLUSE HOUSE OPEN DAY
The 19th-century museum opens its doors to celebrate 100 years as a public museum. William Charles Wentworth, his wife Sarah and their 10 children called this sprawling joint home: share the beauty of this property, with pony rides, vintage games, music and food made from historic recipes – plus there's birthday cake. ST
SUNDAY, OCTOBER 11, 11AM-4PM, VAUCLUSE HOUSE, WENTWORTH ROAD, VAUCLUSE, FREE ENTRY, COST FOR PONY RIDES, SLM.IS/100.
7. FAMILY: RIDES FESTIVAL
The city's annual bike fest launches at Sydney Park, with tracks, workshops and other fun treats like a visit from Taronga Zoo's native animals and an edible garden and planting demo. ST
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 7AM-2PM, SYDNEY PARK, PRINCES HIGHWAY, ST PETERS, FREE. FESTIVAL RUNS UNTIL OCTOBER 31, SEE SYDNEYCYCLEWAYS.NET .
8. STAGE: MAYHEM
In 1969, Chicago mobster Joseph Testa came to town and held a big bash at the Chequers Club – apparently it's most scandalous party to date. There's no gangsters in attendance on this occasion (we hope), but hark back to the days of Chequers with this '60s dress-up extravaganza with yarns from real-life '60s showgirl Elizabeth Burton and cabaret shows including dancing by Bella Louche (pictured). ST
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 6.30PM-9.30PM, JUSTICE & POLICE MUSEUM, CNR ALBERT AND PHILLIP STREETS, $75, SLM.IS/MAYHEM.
9. MUSIC: RUFINO AND THE COCONUTS
Led by the extravagantly named Rufino the Catalan Casanova, this act held court at the Spiegeltent at the Sydney Festival earlier this year. They're back with their first headline show at Goodgod, expect a bonkers approach to dance music mixing '60s guitars, '80s synth and, er, Harry Belafonte. ST
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 8PM-10.30PM, GOODGOD SMALL CLUB, 53-55 LIVERPOOL STREET, CITY, $20, GOODGODGOODGOD.COM .
10. FAMILY: STAR WARS READS DAY
Anticipation is building up for the next tranche of these fairytale sci-fi epics, looming at Christmas with Star Wars: The Force Awakens . They'll be readings, games, crafts and more across the city's libraries. ST
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 11AM-4PM, VARIOUS LOCATIONS, WHATSON.CITYOFSYDNEY.NSW.GOV.AU , FREE.
11. FOOD: PARRAMATTA LANES
The annual fest weaves its way around Parramatta CBD, in a celebration of food, art, music and bars, with tucker from local restaurants including Jamie's and food trucks featuring treats from Cantina Mobil and the Nighthawk Diner. ST
Friday, October 9, 5pm-10pm, various locations, free, parramattalanes.com.au 
12. MUSIC: KISS
Paul Stanley, Gene Simmons, Tommy Thayer and Eric Singer still continue to prove that it's OK for sixtysomething men to wear sparkly spandex and full make-up. Fresh from a European tour and possibly the best cruise ship jaunt ever in a five-day Kiss Fruise out of Miami, they bring their Spider stage production, complete with 900 pyrotechnics pieces. Reassuringly never low-key. Supported by Dead Daisies. ST
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, ALLPHONES ARENA, $99.91-$254.88, TICKETEK.COM.AU 
13. MUSIC: OXFORD ART FACTORY
To celebrate eight years of being in business, the Oxford Art Factory a throwing a free party featuring bearded songsmith Steve Smyth, alt country rockers Papa Pilko and the Binrats, four-piece Smaal Cats, garage rockers Los Tones and rockers Persian Drugs. LR
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 7PM, OXFORD ART FACTORY, DARLINGHURST, RSVP AT MOSHTIX.COM.AU 
14. FESTIVAL: GRAPHIC
Nerd alert! The Opera House will be swarming with geeks (in the nicest possible way) as the Graphic festival hosts a weekend of graphic storytelling, animation and music. There's a range of free and ticketed talks (top pick: George Miller talks Mad Max), screenings (top pick: The Walking Dead season 6 premiere) and artist signings. LR
OCTOBER 10-11, VARIOUS TIMES, SYDNEY OPERA HOUSE, FULL DETAILS AND TICKETS AT GRAPHIC.SYDNEYOPERAHOUSE.COM 
15. MUSIC: SARAH BLASKO
Here's a world exclusive (the show, not this listing): Sydney songstress Sarah Blasko is previewing her new album, Eternal Return , while artist Mike Daly provides specially commissioned visuals to go with it. Say it with me: "Ooooh, pretty". LR
SUNDAY, OCTOBER 11, 9.30PM, SYDNEY OPERA HOUSE, $39-$89, SYDNEYOPERAHOUSE.COM 
16. FILM BLACK MASS
Johnny Depp puts in a ferocious performance as Boston gangster "Whitey" Bulger, with Joel Edgerton also excelling as an FBI agent who grew up with him in the tough crime drama Black Mass . GM
Cinemas everywhere
17. FILM: MISS YOU ALREADY
Directed by Catherine Hardwicke ( Twilight , Thirteen ), Miss You Already is an emotional drama about female friendship under trying circumstances. The drawcard is Toni Collette as Milly, who has to battle breast cancer with support from Drew Barrymore's Jess.
GM
ON THE TOWN FOR
18. The Night Noodle Markets are back in action for Good Food Month. Highlights this year include Toko, Ramen Zundo and Black Star Pastry and N2 Gelato. UNTIL OCTOBER 25, HYDE PARK, CITY, FREE, SYDNEY.GOODFOODMONTH.COM 
19. Celebrate John Lennon's 75th birthday with this rare screening of the documentary Imagine . Even better, there's a $100 prize for the best Lennon lookalike. FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9, 9PM, CREMORNE ORPHEUM, $20, ORPHEUM.COM.AU 
20. Comic Cam Knight brings back his hit show, Almost Bulletproof , for one night only – and it's being filmed for DVD, too. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10, 7PM, COMEDY STORE, MOORE PARK, $22.50, COMEDYSTORE.COM.AU .
